context.p: To install Eucalyptus on servers running CentOS 6 or RHEL 6:

step.cmd: Configure the Eucalyptus package repository on each host that will run a Eucalyptus component:

info.p: Enter y when prompted to install this package.

step.cmd: If you are not a Eucalyptus subscriber, skip this step. If you are a Eucalyptus subscriber, you should have received an rpm package file containing your license for subscription-only components. Install that package, along with the Eucalyptus subscription package, on each host that will run a Eucalyptus component, as follows:

info.p: Enter y when prompted to install this package.

step.cmd: Configure the Euca2ools package repository on each host that will run a Eucalyptus component or Euca2ools:

info.p: Enter y when prompted to install this package.

step.cmd: Configure the EPEL package repository on each host that will run a Eucalyptus component or Euca2ools:

info.p: Enter y when prompted to install this package.

step.cmd: If you are using Walrus as your object storage backend configure the ELRepo repository on each machine that will run Walrus. Otherwise, skip this step.

info.p: Enter y when prompted to install this package.

step.cmd: For RHEL 6 systems, you must enable the Optional repository in Red Hat Network for each NC, as follows:

substep.cmd: Go to http://rhn.redhat.com and navigate to the system that will run the NC.
Make sure the RHEL Server Optional checkbox is checked.

step.cmd: If you are a Eucalyptus subscriber and use VMware Broker, install the VMware Broker packages on the host that will run your Cluster Controller (CC), as follows:

info.p: Enter y when prompted to install this package.

step.note: Clouds that use the VMware hypervisor do not have NCs; if you plan to use VMware then skip this step.

substep.cmd: Install the Eucalyptus node controller software on each planned NC host:
Check that the KVM device node has proper permissions.

info.p: Verify the output shows that the device node is owned by user root and group kvm.
If your kvm device node does not have proper permissions, you need to reboot your NC host.

step.note: Skip this step ff you plan to use VMware.
step.cmd: If you plan to run in Edge networking mode, install the package for Edge support on each planned NC host.
On each planned CLC host, install the Eucalyptus cloud controller software.
Install the Imaging Worker image package on the machine hosting the primary CLC:

Install the software for the remaining Eucalyptus components. The following example shows most components being installed on the same host. We recommend that you use different hosts for each component:
If you would like Load Balancer support enabled in your Cloud, you will need to install the Load Balancer image package on the machine hosting the primary CLC:
If you are a subscriber and use SAN, run the appropriate command for your device on each machine hosting a CLC:
If you are a subscriber and use SAN, run the appropriate command for your device on each machine hosting a SC:

info.note: To use Eucalyptus with EMC SAN support, you must have the NaviCLI-Linux-64-latest.rpm package installed on each SC. This package is not supplied with Eucalyptus, please see your SAN vendor if it is not already installed.

step.cmd: After you have installed Eucalyptus, test multicast connectivity between each CLC and OSG, SC, and VMware broker host.

substep.cmd: Run the network-tomography tool on the Cloud Controller, Cluster Controller, Storage Controller, and any machines running Walrus or VMware Broker, passing a list of IP addresses for each of these machines.
substep.info: cd deveutils/network-tomography ./network-tomography 192.168.51.174 192.168.51.196 192.168.51.86 192.168.51.99 This tool may take up to an hour to run. Check the output for reports of packet loss. If there is significant packet loss, ensure that your network is available and multicast enabled.

substep.cmd: Repeat these tasks with the secondary controllers.

taskbody.postreq: You are now ready to Configure Eucalyptus.
